question_stem: The graph of \(y = g(x)\) intersects the x-axis at \((-2, 0)\), \((1, 0)\), and \((5, 0)\), and the y-axis at \((0, -5)\).

parts.question_text: The function \(h(x)\) is defined as \(h(x) = g(x) + 10\).  Find the coordinates of the points where \(y = h(x)\) crosses the coordinate axes.
parts.solution_text:
The x-intercepts of \(g(x)\) occur when \(g(x) = 0\).  Since \(h(x) = g(x) + 10\), the x-intercepts of \(h(x)\) occur when \(g(x) + 10 = 0\), or \(g(x) = -10\).  We don't know the full form of \(g(x)\), so we can't determine these x-intercepts. 

The y-intercept of \(g(x)\) occurs when \(x = 0\), and is \(g(0) = -5\).  The y-intercept of \(h(x)\) occurs when \(x = 0\), and is \(h(0) = g(0) + 10 = -5 + 10 = 5\).  Therefore, the y-intercept of \(h(x)\) is \((0, 5)\). 

So, the graph of \(y=h(x)\) crosses the y-axis at \((0, 5)\).  We cannot determine where it crosses the x-axis without more information about \(g(x)\).
